CSE 570 Wireless/Mobile Networking (Fall 2014)

Grading

Occasional quizzes and homeworks (33%), midterm and final exam (33%), term project – in groups of 2-3, solo project is also acceptable, but not ideal (34%). If significant work is done in project – specifically developing a useful tool or analysis, you can choose to shift more weight to the project.

Record of class activities and readings

Wireless physical layer
  • Slides used in 1st lecture (9/3) on wireless physical layerExternal Link
  • Text used for wireless physical layer: COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS ENGINEERING, Proakis and Salehi, Prentice Hall, 2002 Ed. (see sec 7.6 for bit error rate analysis for binary PAM etc.)
  • Nitin Vaidya's notes. See Chapter 2 for wireless physical layer. External Link
  • Lecture on (9/8): time domain and freq. domain representation, basic concepts of Fourier Series and Transforms, Shannon's capacity law, concept of dB, dBm. Difference between capacity, bit rate, throughput, bandwidth. Read Vaidya's notes - Chapter 2.
  • Lecture on (9/9): BER vs. SINR for 802.11. Friis path loss equation. Path loss calculator. Also, Read Vaidya's notes - Chapter 2, everything regarding path loss. Survey paper on wireless path loss and coverage prediction. Read at least Sec IIIA, Sec IVC and skim through the rest.
Localization of wireless devices
  • Lecture on (9/15): Localization. Two basic methods – based on ranging using signal strength, timing, etc., and based on finger printing. Location Systems tutorial paper by A. Lamarca and E. De Lara. At the minimum, read Sec 2.3, 2.4 for GPS, Sec 4.1, 4.2 and 5.1, 5.2, 5.4 for WiFi and cellular networks.
White space spectrum and secondary operation
  • Lecture on (9/17): TV White Space. General idea of TVWS, concept of protection region and spectrum databases. Slides. Read this paper:Farzad Hessar, Sumit Roy: Capacity Considerations for Secondary Networks in TV White Space. Sec 1,2,3,4 and Appendix A.
Medium access control protocols
  • Lecture on (9/22): Medium access control protocol. Scheduled and random access protocols. Aloha. Carrier-sensing. Read Vaidya's notes above - Chapter 3.
  • Lecture on 9/24: Discussion on project topics. Medium access control protocols to continue from next class.
  • Lecture on 9/29: Aloha continued. Carrier sensing. Read Vaidya's notes above - Chapter 3. Quiz 2 on next class.
  • Lecture on 10/1: CSMA protocol continued, RTS/CTS. Also, Quiz 2.
  • Lecture on 10/6,8,13: CSMA protocol, analysis, 802.11 protocol. Vaidya's notes above is the key ref. You are expected to be familiar with 802.11 DCF schemes (with and without RTS/CTS). If you need additional refs, use SecII of this paper. It provides some details of IFS and slot times (but it does not describe RTS/CTS, also neglects to mention that backoff counter is frozen if medium is sensed busy). If you want to learn about various management functions such as association, authentication, power save mode, various frame details, etc. use this or this.
  • Slides on MAC protocols from Vaidya's notes. Note that not all concepts were used in class and these slides are directly from his notes.
Routing protocols
  • Lecture on 10/15: Thought question: why new routing is needed in wireless/mobile networks? Concepts of infrastructure network and ad hoc/mesh networks. Table driven routing and source routing. Proactive and reactive (or on-demand) routing. Reading: Nitin Vaidya's notes (Chapter 6). Review: undergraduate level network routing topics: IP addressing and forwarding, IPv4 frame formats, link state and distance vector routing. Any undergraduate level reference is fine. If you are looking for a recommendation, use Kurose and Ross's textbook. This is widely available as it is a popular text, even an older edition is fine.
  • Lecture on 10/20: Link state routing, various optimizations on broadcast. Supplement Vaidya's notes with some notes that I prepared.
  • Lecture on 10/22: Flooding, optimizations. On demand routing. Dynamic source routing protocol. Slides used (note only slides 1-19 and 64-66 are used). Original DSR paper: David B. Johnson and David A. Maltz. Dynamic Source Routing in Ad Hoc Wireless Networks. In Mobile Computing, edited by Tomasz Imielinski and Hank Korth, Chapter 5, pages 153-181, Kluwer Academic Publishers, 1996.
  • Lecture on 11/3: Lecture by Zafar Qazi on Mobile IP. Slides used. References: 1) Mobile Networking Through Mobile IP (Tutorial), Charles Perkins. Dated, but still useful and very easy reading. 2) Charles Perkins (ed), IP Mobility Support, RFC 2002, The RFC on Mobile IP. 3) RFC 3024 - Reverse Tunneling for Mobile IP, revised.
  • Lecture on 11/5: AODV protocol. Readings: Charles E. Perkins and Elizabeth M. Royer. "Ad hoc On-Demand Distance Vector Routing." Proceedings of the 2nd IEEE Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications, New Orleans, LA, February 1999. Also read the AODV RFC: Charles E. Perkins, Elizabeth M. Belding-Royer, and Samir Das. "Ad Hoc On Demand Distance Vector (AODV) Routing." IETF RFC 3561, July 2003. RFC is the most definitive description of any Internet-based protocol. A high level understanding of use of sequence no. is acceptable though not directly covered in class. In this regard review general distance vector protocols (e.g., RIP) for the Internet and review why loops should occur in those protocols. Use slides from before.
  • Lecture on 11/10: Mesh networks and routing metrics Slides used. Read sec 1 and sec 2 of this paper: Richard Draves, Jitendra Padhye, and Brian Zill, "Comparison of routing metrics for static multi-hop wireless networks." Proc. SIGCOMM'04. EXOR routing protocol. Read Sec. 1-3 of this paper: Sanjit Biswas and Robert Morris, "ExOR: opportunistic multi-hop routing for wireless networks," In Proc. SIGCOMM'05.
  • Lecture on 11/12: Geographic routing. The class slides are here. Also, read these notes. The GPSR paper is here. More on face routing in this paper.
  • Routing topic not covered directly: Disruption-tolerant routing.
Transport layer
  • Lecture on 11/17, 11/19: TCP over wireless links. Slides. Only upto ELN covered in class. Notes. Also, the original ELN paper is here.

    • Visualization of the RSS data as a heat map
    • A reference paper that does similar modeling for WiFi (see sec 3.1 and Fig 3). External Link
    • A good pointer for info on how to compute distance from a given pair of <lat,long> coordinates: External Link. Sample python script below.
       def distance(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2)
          lon1, lat1, lon2, lat2 = map(radians, [lon1, lat1, lon2, lat2])
          dlon = lon2 - lon1 
          dlat = lat2 - lat1 
          a = sin(dlat/2)**2 + cos(lat1) * cos(lat2) * sin(dlon/2)**2
          c = 2 * atan2(sqrt(a), sqrt(1-a)) 
          meters = 6367 * c * 1000
          return meters

Term Project

Ground Rules

Typically 2-3 students per project. A proportionately more complete work is expected from a 3 students group than 2. (You can also go solo if you like; but it is easier to work in a group as projects could be involved and also it is easier for us to manage projects if there are fewer of them.)

Several ideas are provided in a following ideas document. This document will be evolving within the next week. You are not limited to these ideas. But these are the ideas we have some concrete interest in and so they are fairly well-defined and also novel.

Your eventual deliverable is a report plus necessary code/prototype system as appropriate.

Time line

Expect to provide intermediate checkpoints. Each checkpoint is a short progress report describing your project, scope of work, your approach, etc plus activities undertaken/results obtained including next steps. Checkpoints are optional. They are used to monitor progress and gather feedback; they are not used for grading. But experience has shown that students who miss checkpoints or do poorly at checkpoints also do poorly in the project. Each project will need to be demoed and also a final report is to be submitted.

  • Checkpoint 1 - Oct 15 Oct 22
  • Checkpoint 2 - Nov 10 Nov 12
  • Demo - Nov 25
  • Final report due - Dec 2 Dec 10 Dec 13

Your grade will depend on both the demo (what is working, how well) and also the report (how well you can describe the problem you are trying to address, related work and your approach/results). Grade will also depend on the complexity of your project/scope of work.

Guideline for Project Report

The best report is about 4-6 pages formatted just like a research paper. Just like a research paper, your report should have an introduction that introduces the problem you are solving and provides appropriate background. Then it discusses the methodology. Here you describe, for example, your experimental platform, experimental design, rationale for such design, any limitations/approximations, data collection and analysis or software development effort as appropriate, etc. Then the report provides the actual results and observations. Finally, it concludes with a summary of the work and pointers to future work. Note that this is a general guideline only and specifics will depend on your actual work.

Though you will not be penalized for longer or shorter reports or using a different format, try to limit to 4-6 pages assuming you are formatting as typical research papers are formatted (e.g., 11 point times roman font, double column, 0.5-1 inch margin on sides, tightly integrated figures/plots/charts etc. Also, be careful in choosing what data to present and how. Do not try to present everything that you have collected. For example, a single plot can be more informative than printouts of pages of tables/data. Similarly, refrain from providing code as a part of the report. However, pseudo code is fine if it highlights a core point. When presenting plots, make sure to label the axes. Provide captions to all figures and plots. If there is anything non-essential you want to discuss in the report, relegate that to an appendix.

To summarize, your report should be a cogent, easily readable technical document and not a journal log or dump of your work. It should highlight real technical challenges and solutions you developed. It should be written in a focused fashion with a goal to educate and inform the reader rather than to confuse. This is the reason it best to stick to the page limit guidelines above. No project really needs more than this amount of space to clearly present and explain the contributions.

You will have an opportunity to submit code and data separately with the report.
